column1: #Text=Digital security researchers publicly reveal vulnerability in WPA2 WiFi protocol

#Text=On Monday , digital security researchers Mathy Vanhoef and Frank Piessens of Belgium 's KU Leuven university publicly disclosed a security vulnerability in the WPA2 Wi-Fi ( wireless local-area networking ) protocol , which they called KRACK ( for K ey R einstallation A tta ck ) .
#Text=Their study claimed KRACK affects every modern device using Wi-Fi ; it can be fixed by a software update , researchers said .
#Text=Vanhoef wrote , " Attackers can use this novel attack technique to read information that was previously assumed to be safely encrypted .

#Text=The Wi-Fi Alliance said it  could be resolved through a straightforward software update . "

column1: #Text=OpenBSD released their software patch on August 30 .
#Text=Exploring the flaw which affected every device the researchers had tested , National Cyber Security Centre of the UK said " the attacker would have to be physically close to the target " .
#Text=But due to this flaw , an attacker can send malware or ransomware on the websites , Vanhoef claimed .

#Text=Linux -based operating systems including Android v6.0 and higher are especially affected by this flaw , while Windows and iOS are not as vulnerable as Android by this flaw as they do not fully implement WPA2 .
#Text=Microsoft reportedly has released security patches for Windows 7 , 8 , 8.1 and 10 .
#Text=Google said Android operating systems would receive the updates in the software update scheduled to be made available on November 6 .
#Text=Apple has implemented the patch in the beta versions of their operating system iOS , macOS , tvOS and watchOS , however it is yet to roll out patches for stable operating systems .
#Text=WPA2 protocol has been used for more than a decade , and has been compulsory for Wi-Fi since 2006 .
#Text=KRACK would also affect various home appliances which can be controlled over Wi-Fi , within the so-called " Internet of things " .
